0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Acquired combined coagulation factor deficiency, Due to liver disease or undergoing cardiac surgery or liver transplant - Transfusion of coagulation factors: initial, 10 to 15 mL/kg IV resulting in 15% to 25% increase in plasma coagulation factor levels; adjust based on desired clinical response
  • Plasma exchange - Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura: 40 to 60 mL/kg IV for complete plasma volume replacement during plasmapheresis

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: efficacy and safety have not been evaluated in pediatric patients

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Acquired combined coagulation factor deficiency, Due to liver disease or undergoing cardiac surgery or liver transplant - Transfusion of coagulation factors
  • Plasma exchange - Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to fresh frozen plasma, plasma-derived products including any plasma protein, or any component of the product
  • IgA deficiency
  • protein S deficiency, severe

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• human plasma derivative; infectious agent risk, including viruses and theoretical risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • infusion rates, high; increased risk of hypervolemia with pulmonary edema or cardiac failure; monitoring recommended
  • plasmin inhibitor (alpha2-antiplasmin), low levels; increased risk of excessive bleeding or hyperfibrinolysis; monitoring recommended for patients undergoing liver transplantation
  • thrombosis may occur; monitoring recommended
  • transfusion reactions may occur; verify ABO-blood group compatibility
  • volumes exceeding 1 mL/kg/min; increased risk of citrate toxicity
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Pruritus (1% or greater), Urticaria (1% or greater)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (1% or greater)
  • Neurologic:Headache (1% or greater), Paresthesia (1% or greater)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac arrest, Hypotension, Severe
  • Immunologic:Anaphylactoid reaction
  • Respiratory:Respiratory arrest
  • Other:Citrate adverse reaction

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Pooled solvent- or detergent-treated human plasma is comprised of plasma proteins such as albumin, immunoglobulins, other globulins, coagulation factors, complement proteins and protease inhibitors, and is used to replace human plasma proteins.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • to thaw in water bath: thaw in outer wrapper up to 30 minutes in a circulating water bath at 30 to 37 degrees C (86 to 98.6 degrees F); may use overwrap bag if appropriate; prevent water from contaminating the entry port
  • to thaw with dry tempering system, place bag between heating plates according to the manufacturer's instructions, between 30 to 37 degrees C (86 to 98.6 degrees F); remove when thawing process is complete; may be monitored and recorded with thawing device printer or barcode scanner recommended by the device manufacturer
  • avoid shaking; do not refreeze
  • base therapy on ABO-blood group compatibility to avoid transfusion reactions
  • use an infusion set with a filter for administration

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• aPTT, prothrombin time (PT), and specific coagulation factors; during therapy for response
  • achievement of hemostasis may indicate efficacy
  • signs and symptoms of pulmonary edema or cardiac failure; during therapy, especially with high infusion rates
  • signs of excessive bleeding in liver transplant patients
  • thrombosis in patients at risk (eg, low levels of Protein S)

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to immediately report symptoms of thrombosis, pulmonary edema, or cardiac failure.
  • Tell patient to immediately report symptoms of citrate toxicity (eg, paresthesia, fatigue, muscle spasms).
  • This drug may cause headache, nausea, or pruritus.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of flu-like or other viral infections, as the product is made from human plasma and may carry a small risk of transmitting infectious agents (eg, viruses and theoretically, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease agent).
